_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR 2745.3)


ES1.0	FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
Grow West is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it has operations by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. The owners, management, and employees of Dixon Wholesale, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Dixon Facility or Facility) at 7235 Tremont Road, Dixon, California 95620 are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia. 

Grow West has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with both the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations to address process and operational safety. If an accidental release were to occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate the release and to minimize the impact of the release on people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Response Program (ERP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release. 


ES2.0	FACILITY INFORMATION
The Dixon Wholesale Facility provides fertilizers and related products to farmers and other agricultural supply operations. The Facilitys primary activity is the sale of liquid fertilizers (including anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and 10-34-0), granular fertilizers (prill), and a variety of non bulk, pre packaged chemicals (e.g., herbicides and pesticides) to farmers in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers) and 325311 (Nitrogenous Fertilizer Manufacturing). The Dixon Wholesale Facility is not collocated within one mile from another regulated facility and has not had a reportable accident within the last five years. No practicability assessment for inherently safer technology or design (IST/ISD) is required. The Dixon Facility has bee

n assigned the U.S. EPA Facility Identifier number 1000-0002-8793.

~~~~~
Anhydrous Ammonia
--- The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia in inventory exceeds the U.S. EPA regulatory threshold of 10,000 lbs and the CalARP threshold of 500 lbs. 

--- Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is received, stored, converted, reacted, and distributed for application as a crop production nutrient. 

--- Anhydrous ammonia is a liquefied, compressed gas that is shipped in DOT approved trucks and offloaded into on-site pressure vessels (a.k.a., bullets). 

--- Anhydrous ammonia, as a liquefied compressed gas, will boil under ambient atmospheric conditions. Liquid ammonia will expand by 850 times when evaporating. 

--- The anhydrous ammonia is offloaded from the delivery vehicles and pumped into either the 18,000 gallon storage tank or a 30,050-gallon storage tank. 

--- Dixon Wholesale will either sell the anhydrous ammonia for direct application (via DOT nurse tanks), will convert the anhydrous ammonia into aqua ammonia (ammonium hydroxide), or will react the anhydrous ammonia with super phosphoric acid (SPA ) to produce ammonium polyphosphate (10-34-0) fertilizer.

--- The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 

--- The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 209,928 pounds.

----- Storage Vessel (bullet) 1 -
18,000 gallons | 15,300 gallons (at 85% full) | mass NH3 is 78,642 lbs

----- Storage Vessel (bullet) 2 -
30,050 gallons | 15,300 gallons (at 85% full) | mass NH3 is 131,286 lbs

----- Total storage (bullets 1 and 2) -
48,050 gallons | 40,842 gallons (at 85% full) | mass NH3 is 209,928 lbs

~~~~~
Aqua Ammonia
--- The maximum amount of aqua ammonia in inventory exceeds the U.S. EPA regulatory threshold of 20,000 lbs and the CalARP threshold of 500 lbs. 

--- Aqua ammonia is produced from anhydrous ammonia and stored in two tanks, Tank 24 has a shell capacity of 25,000 gallon and Tank 25 has a shell capacity of 10,000 gallons. 

--- Vo

lume and mass reported in this RMP assume that the aqua ammonia tanks are filled to their working capacity (i.e., working volume). 

--- The aqua ammonia tanks are located with secondary containment.

--- The aqua ammonia load-out racks are located within secondary containment. 
 
--- The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 266,000 pounds. The maximum amount of ammonia (present as NH3) in the aqua ammonia solution is 64,750 lbs.

----- Tank 24 (AQ2) -
25,000 gallons | 190,000 lbs of NH4OH (24.3%) | mass NH3 is 46,250 lbs

----- Tank 25 (AQ3)  -
10,000 gallons | 76,000 lbs of NH4OH (24.3%) | mass NH3 is 18,500 lbs

----- Total storage (Tanks 24 and 25) -
35,000 gallons | 266,000 lbs of NH4OH (24.3%) | mass NH3 is 64,750 lbs


ES3.0	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

--- Process Safety Information (PL3) | Safety Information (PL2).  
The Facility ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. Items include Safety Data Sheets (SDSs), chemical inventories, operating limits (temperatures, pressures, flows, compositions), equipment specifications, and Codes and Standards used to design, build, and operate the process. For PL3, the information includes diagrams, safety systems, and materials of construction. 

--- Process Hazards Analysis (PL3) | Hazard Review (PL2).  
A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. A review of the results from the most recent hazard review update for the anhydrous ammonia process, aqua ammonia process, and pesticide handling and storage indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.

--- Operating Procedures.  
Written operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes. The operating procedures for the anhydrous ammonia are reviewed and recertified on an

annual basis. The operating procedures for the aqua ammonia and the regulated pesticide are reviewed, revised, and recertified in accordance with regulatory requirements. 

--- Training.  
Facility staff and Grow West corporate staff understand that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The current training program is comprised of the following:
1.  Initial employee training.
2.  Periodic refresher training.
3.  Training provided for new equipment additions or modifications.
4.  Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and
5.  Training records for each employee.

--- Mechanical Integrity (PL3) And Maintenance (PL2).  
Dixon Wholesale has implemented a Mechanical Integrity / Maintenance program for its regulated substances. The program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The program includes equipment inspection, preventive maintenance, recordkeeping, and training and is conducted in accordance with manufacturers requirements, and industry practices (e.g., Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices, RAGAGEP). 

--- Management Of Change (PL3).  
Operational, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures.

--- Pre-Startup Safety Review (PL3).  
The pre-startup safety review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications

to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a PSSR. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. Additionally, a PSSR is performed in conjunction with the MOC review process when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety or operational procedures.

--- Compliance Audits.  
Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan are conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. 

--- Incident Investigation.  
Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident.

--- Employee Participation (PL3).  
The Facility relies upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, providing access to safety documentation, and seeking employee knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. 

--- Hot Work Permit (PL3).  
For hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, Grow West has developed a written Hot Work Permit program and procedure to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. 

--- Contractor Safety (PL3).  
The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contract

ors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. The Facility also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely.

--- Other Code Applicability.  
The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):

Regulated Substances
--- United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans. 

--- United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 68, Subpart E, Emergency Response.

Anhydrous Ammonia 
--- United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.

--- California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders.

--- Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]

Anhydrous Ammonia and Aqua Ammonia
--- American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping.

--- California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials.


ES4.0	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, or regulated pesticides during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation(s), a shelter in-place order, or property or environmental damage.


ES5.0	THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facilitys emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) requirements. The facility also developed an Emergency Response Program (

ERP) in accordance with the requirements presented in the CalARP regulations Section 2745.8. The ERP will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.


ES6.0	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Safety is integral to the operations at Dixon Wholesale. Implementing safety improvements is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and regulated pesticide processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.


ES7.0	THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
Grow West, Dixon Wholesale conducted offsite consequence analyses (OCA) for the three processes at the facility. The OCAs evaluated the Worst-Case Release Scenario (as defined in regulation) and an Alternative Release Scenario (i.e., the more likely condition). 

--- Anhydrous Ammonia.  
The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount. That tank holds a maximum of 131,286 pounds (25,542 gallons) of anhydrous ammonia. The distance to toxic endpoint is 2.61 miles. The alternative release scenario, identified by Grow West during the process hazards analysis (PHA), is a release from a 2 inch pipe which lasts 2 minutes. That release would have a distance to toxic endpoint of 1.18 miles. 

--- Aqua Ammonia.  
The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to 25,000 gallons. The 190,000 pound release of aqua ammonia solution (equivalent to 46,250 pounds of NH3) to the secondary containment would have a distance to toxic endpoint of 1.51 miles. The alternative release scenario is a release from a hose that is collected in secondary containment (assumed as 10,000 pounds of solution, or 1,315 gallons). That release would have a distance to toxic endpoint of 0.19 miles.
